analystresearch2002 wrote:

>   I am a consultant working for a software company who has asked me to
> recommend new testing frameworks that will be becoming useful in the era
> of web services.
> 
>   I've run across test driven development - which appears to be a
> process of having developers develop JUnit tests before they write any
> code (i.e. document the symantics before you go to implementation)
> 
>   I've also run into automated unit testing - which appears to be a
> product concept:  reducing the burden of developers creating tests
> themselves - companies like Agitar and Parasoft are playing here.

What Agitar and Parasoft do is no more "automated unit testing" than 
JUnit/TDD. It's all automated unit testing: automating unit tests.

What Parasoft does is suggest tests for basic, generic boundary 
conditions. It's useful for testing legacy code.

What Agitar does includes (but is not limited to) identifying behavioral 
invariants for code, making it easy to promote those to assertions in 
JUnit tests. The idea appears to be that if something is invariant now, 
then you'd like it to be invariant from this day forward, so put it in a 
test. This looks absolutely /killer/ for testing legacy code.

>   I would like some feedback: what are the pro's and con's of these
> solutions?  Are there other solutions?  What types of companies would
> benefit from either of these?  What are the risks or downsides of
> using these systems?  Do you recommend either TDD or AUT and why?

I have no experience with Parasoft's or Agitar's products, /however/ I 
know others who do have such experience and am relaying some of that here.

I recommend test-driving all new code. This is especially good for 
greenfield projects, where /everything/ is new code. The advantages are 
numerous and well-documented: 100% coverage, simpler cleaner designs, a 
safety net for changes... the only disadvantage is not really a TDD 
problem, but a learning problem--you have to learn how to do TDD.

If you need to add tests to existing code, Agitar's product looks like 
it would help out immensely in identifying what the product already does 
and making it easier to turn that information into regression tests.

Most projects need to do both: add features (new code) and fix features 
(legacy code), and so I recommend test-driving the new features and 
using something like Agitar's product to help add tests to the existing 
code.
